A meeting to discuss the American
Student Union and to elect delegates
to attend the founding convention in
Columbus, Ohio, will be held on
Wednesday at 4 p. m. in Levering
Hall under the auspices of the NEWSLETTER, Y. M. C. A., and National
Student League.
Faculty speakers and representatives of interested student organiza- ons will discuss the need for student unity and the aims and purposes of the proposed Union.
The new Union is intended to replace the National Student League
-id the Student League for Industrial Democracy but to be considerly broader than either of them. It
is designed to attract those students
who have not hitherto belonged to
any organized student groups. The
program of the Union will be drawn
up at the national convention by the
delegates themselves.
Delegates from clubs and from
unaffiliated students will be sent on
'he basis of two delegates for the
first ten members and one for each
ten thereafter.
The convention dales are December 28 and 29 and the place the campus of the Ohio State University in
Columbus, Ohio.

The annual winter meetings of the
associations of members of college
faculties which will be held throughout the country the week of the
Christmas recess will attract many
members of the faculty of the Johns
Hopkins University.
The first meeting will be that of
the American Historical Association
which will meet in Chattanooga. Dr.
r. Stull Holt, associate professor of
history, will be a discussion group
leader on the foreign affairs of the
Jnited States. Dr. Kent R. Greenfield, professor of modern European
history, will lie a member of the
committee on the arrangement of the
program. Dr. Johannes 11/Vattern, lecturers in political science and Dr.
James Hart, associate professor of
political science will also attend.
Dr. Robinson To Speak
Dr. David M. Robinson, professor
of archaeology and epigraphy, will be
present at the meeting of the American Philological Association in New
York where he will deliver a paper
on "Pindar and His Inuences." Later
the same week Dr. Robinson will, before the Archaeological Institute of
America, give a paper on "Unpublished Vases."
Dean Edward W. Berry, of the
College of Arts and Sciences and professor of paleontology, will attend the
meeting of the Geological Society of
America at New York.
. A. G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering, and J. C. Smallwood, associate professor of mechanical engineering, attended the convention of the American Society of
Mechanical Engineers held last week
at New York. At this meeting Harwood F. Mullikan, Hopkins graduate of 1930, delivered a series of
three papers on his work on heat absorption in boiler furnaces.
Church Yearley Elected

On Friday, December 14, the Association of Gas Engineers of Johns
Hopkins University held their se^ond monthly meeting. The Association was addressed by Dr. Lloyd L.
Logan of the Gas Department of the
School of Engineering.
Dr. Logan
chose as his topic his experiences in
the engineering field. He has been
employed by

the General Electric
Company, Stone-Webster Engineering Company of Boston, and the Union Sulphur Company. Dr. Logan saw
active service overseas with the Engineering Corps of the Canadian Expeditionary Forces. Work on change
of color as determined by photoelectric effect and synthesis of metals
done at the Massachusetts Institute
of Technology and at the Hopkins respectively have been reetnt problems engaging Dr. Logan.
Both Dr. Wilbert James Huff and
Dr. Logan are honorary members of
the Gas Engineers Association. Juniors and Seniors who are Gas majors
are automatically members. Officers
for this year are E. Gray, president;
J. Machek, vice-president; George
Kornmann, secretary; and R. B.
Young (treasurer). The Association
meets once a month in room 110,
Maryland Hall, and endeavors to
have lecturers of prominence address
the group.

"Depression Is Over",
Says Dr. Kouwenhoven
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven, professor of electrical engineering and
asistant dean of the engineering faculty, in commenting on the employment situation for graduate engineers, stated that since September 1
there has been an unprecedented upswing in the demands for graduate
engineers which he has been unable
to meet with the lists in his office.
He said, "It appears that we are
now on the upswing from the depression."

Board Bans Lunching
In Levering Hall Lobby
At a recent meeting, the Board of
Managers of the Johns Hopkins Y.
M. C. A. ordered that students are
not to eat lunches in the lobby of
Levering Hall.
The Board feels that in view of the
fact that Levering Hall affords both
a cafeteria and a soda fountain
where lunches brought from home
may be eaten, there is no reason why
the lobby should be so used.
The order is to be put into effect
immediately.

Johns Hopkins
A hard-fighting, well-coached, and
drilled team representing Johns Hopkins, fought an experienced Temple
fve to a standstill during the first
half of their annual contest and then
succumbed to the Scarlet foe. A belated rally, marked by remarkable
shooting, caused the fall of Hopkins
before the giants from Philadelphia.
The game was a repetition of last
year's contest: size and numbers
proved the margin between victory
and defeat.

Lotz Presents Medal To Swimmers Meet RandolphMacon Jan. 10; Natators
Winner; Milberg Beaten
In Hardfought Struggle
Practice At City Pool
While an audible rain beat gently
against the window panes, the student body comprising the Dormitory
quieted to a hushed silence as Dr.
John Curtiss of the Mathematics Department was crowned king of Dormitory Ping-Pong.
The announcement of the conclusion of the tournament and its subsequent victor was
made by Ed Lotz, who conducted the
affair.
Dr. Curtiss was presented
-itir the medal emblematic of his
supremacy by Mr. Lotz, and a garland of choice onions by Mrs. Vanneman.

The champion, who ranks high in
the world of tennis, had to defeat the
very cream of the ping-pong crop in
his sensational fight to the fore of
the field. Putting Vinny Giacinto, the
runner-up in last year's tournament,
to an unexpected defeat, the determined Euclidian then employed all
his knowledge of curves, sines, and
logs, to slip by Lupo Goldstein, taming the Amboy Table Tennis Terror.
Opposing the mathematician in the
final round was Iry Milberg, a freshman, who had made a gallant stand
to this point. Displaying an array of
superb shots, deft drives, and beautiful backhands, Dr. Curtiss soon defefeated the yearling.
When asked for a statement concerning his victories, Dr. Curtiss
could only remark, modestly, "I was
superlatively lucky. My opponents
will tell you the same thing."

Randolph-Macon. The Jays go into
action on January 10 to inaugurate
what will be the most extensive season they have ever enjoyed.
The squad is aided greatly by the
daily use of the spacious City College tank, and has already made
much progress towards the goal of
perfect condition. Although weakened somewhat by the loss of several men, particularly both varsity divers, there is an abundance of new
material to compensate for this.
The contest between Hopkins and
Randolph-Macon will mark the first
time the two teams have met, and
the Jays are anxious to successfully
begin the new relationship. While
the Black and Blue seems to have an
edge, based on last year's performances, the encounter will undoubtedly
be close. Thus it will be necessary
for the Jay, squad to be at their full
strength in order to come out in
front, and Coach Hambleton urges
everyone with any ability whatsoever to report for practice, particularly
divers and free stylers.
The results shown so far after
only a short period of training, antic'apate a better season than the 1934
one, in which Hopkins could capture
only two of the seven contests. Although the men performed well in
the last few meets, the squad was
very slow in getting into shape. It is
expected that this condition will be
remedied in the coming campaign by
the daily practice in a larger natatorium.

Ed Lotz Conducts
Boxing Practices
After Christmas Holidays
Tournament Is Planned;
Many Attend Practices
Under the tutelage of Ed Lotz,
erstwhile St. John's star, boxing
practices have been held several
times weekly it the Gym. Some ten
to twenty ring enthusiasts have been
present at these sessions.
Preparations for an extensive intramural boxing tourney are being
made. A definite date has not been
ascertained, but Coach Lotz reported that the tournament will take place
a week or two after the Christmas
holidays.
Practices are conducted in a manner closely similar to those of professional fighters. A regular routine
has been outlined. The men do some
shadow boxing, punch both the light
and heavy bags, and often have short
three-round bouts.
After the holidays, there will be
drills on Monday, Thursday and Friday of each week.
Among the gloved athletes who
have been showing ability in the past
Weeks are Fenwick, Glasser, Dukehart, Stevens, Wiseman, Barker, Bravo, Hoffman, and Steingrob.

U.OfM.Booters
Trim Jay Team
In Close Match
Extra Period Tally Decides
Game; Henderson Boots
Winning Goal For Terps
The Blue Jay booters lost their last
game of the season to the University of Maryland soccer team by a
score of 2-1 at Homewood Saturday.
Not unlike their other defeats, this
fatal fracas was a close game, and
was finally decided after two extra
periods.
It was not until the third period
of the game that the Terps were able
to break into the scoreless game with
a fast goal. On a kick in by Beacham, left inside for University of
Maryland, Cissel managed to thwart
the attacks of the Blue Jays and to
force the ball into the Hopkins net
for the first score of the gante.
The Blue Jays immediately retaliated with a goal in the early part
of the fourth quarter. On a scramble
near the Maryland net, the ball was
in an undecided position until Gough,
playing right inside for the Jays,
charged through
with a beautiful
boot which terminated in the Terrapin's net.
The winning goal of the game was
scored in the extra period by Henderson, who played center full for University of Maryland. Henderson
picked a slow roller from a fellow
Player and booted it from close range
into the Hopkins net.
Every Blue Jay boater turned in a
great performance and Coach Dotterweich expressed his satisfaction with
his team. "We'll be right in there
next year with a better and more
experienced team."

Fraternity Sports
•
The last Saturday in January the
Interfrat Basketball and Volleyball
Leagues will be under way. Reuben
Baer intends to have at least two
games before the mid-years. Therefore, there will not be any games
during the last two weeks in January.
All men who are good enough to
play on either the Varsity, Jay Vee,
or Freshman teams, are ineligible for
fraternity competition. Coach Gardner Mallonee will submit a list of
these who are likely to be ineligible.

Life of a joke:
Birth: A freshman thinks it up and
chuckles with glee, waking up two
fraternity men in the back oow.
Age five minutes: Freshman tells
it to senior, who answers, "Yeah, it's
funny. But I've heard it before."
Age one day: Senior turns it in to
campus paper as his own.
Age two days: Editor thinks its
terrible.

The pathetically ridiculous Duke of
Florence was a synthesis of the same
hems and haws of Fabious Maximus.
the Roman patriarch, plus a most
delectable 'ittle lisp. Frank Morgan's
conception in the Hollywood production could scarcely have been far
superior, and it was certainly no more
mirth provoking.
In commenting upon Gerald Branower's performance, it should be noted that the character of Cellini, the
artist-lover-swordsman, necessitates
a certain amount of over-acting.
Cellini was essentially an egotistical,
over-confident Hotspur, and no characterization of him can, or should,
fail to capitalize on it. The key to
his life may be summed up in his own
words: "I am no liar, I ofn a poet.
A liar makes much out of nothing, a
poet makes more out of very little."
Branower was splendid in the role;
and, in his amazing versatility, he
even outdid his startlingly well-done
Hannibal of last year. Perhaps the
balcony scene was a bit overdone, a
bit too rich; but any such slight fault
in dramatic intensity was easily overshadowed by an otherwise consistent
and convincing performance.
A rose to Cyrile Kader Grant for
the most natural and unaffected performance of the evening. In the
Duchess, we find a truly dominant
personality, a real de Medici. Miss
:ant did not act, she was the Duchess—and from her person emanated
all the haughtiness, the aloofness, the
egotism, that characterized the most
dangerous family in European history. That she could handle men-be they Dukes or Cellinis—was obvious. That she could handle herself was even more obvious. In short,
she clearly exhibited all the figure,
bearing, and vocal quality that mark
histronic talent.
It was a far cry from the humble
Punic slave of the Road to Rome to
the treacherous brother of the Duke
of Florence, Ottaviano. Merel Harmel, a sophomore, who is clearly destined to make a name for himself in
Hopkins histronics, has developed
perceptibly since the last Barnstormer production. Making full use of a
remarkably powerful and penetrating
voice, Harmel played his rol,e with a
bearing and excruciating deliberateness that could not escape being admired. Ottaviano was "a real mean
roan," thanks to an exceptionally sensitive interpretation.
Dolly Ashley, we feel, was not very
convincing as Cellini's model, Angela.
The girl whom the artist "picked out
of the gutter" to be his model and
newest love was a cold, rather shallow, emotionless statue whose heart
could not be reached. Miss Ashley
uld have made much of the role
had she maintained throughout her
performance the rigid frigidity which
she did assume on several occasions.
Although there were in Angela neglected opportunities, her part in the
success of the play cannot be slighted.

A meeting to discuss the American
Student Union and to elect delegates
to attend the founding convention in
Columbus, Ohio, will be held on
Wednesday at 4 p. m. in Levering
Hall under the auspices of the NEWSLETTER, Y. M. C. A., and National
Student League.
Faculty speakers and representatives of interested student organiza- ons will discuss the need for student unity and the aims and purposes of the proposed Union.
The new Union is intended to replace the National Student League
-id the Student League for Industrial Democracy but to be considerly broader than either of them. It
is designed to attract those students
who have not hitherto belonged to
any organized student groups. The
program of the Union will be drawn
up at the national convention by the
delegates themselves.
Delegates from clubs and from
unaffiliated students will be sent on
'he basis of two delegates for the
first ten members and one for each
ten thereafter.

Columbus, Ohio.

Antarctic Geologist •
Speaks In Latrobe

"Depression Is Over",
Says Dr. Kouwenhoven
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven, professor of electrical engineering and
asistant dean of the engineering faculty, in commenting on the employment situation for graduate engineers, stated that since September 1
there has been an unprecedented upswing in the demands for graduate
engineers which he has been unable
to meet with the lists in his office.
He said, "It appears that we are
now on the upswing from the depression."

Board Bans Lunching
In Levering Hall Lobby
At a recent meeting, the Board of
Managers of the Johns Hopkins Y.
M. C. A. ordered that students are
not to eat lunches in the lobby of
Levering Hall.
The Board feels that in view of the
fact that Levering Hall affords both
a cafeteria and a soda fountain
where lunches brought from home
may be eaten, there is no reason why
the lobby should be so used.
The order is to be put into effect
immediately.

before the giants from Philadelphia.
The game was a repetition of last
year's contest: size and numbers
proved the margin between victory
and defeat.

Lotz Presents Medal To Swimmers Meet RandolphMacon Jan. 10; Natators
Winner; Milberg Beaten
In Hardfought Struggle
Practice At City Pool
While an audible rain beat gently
against the window panes, the student body comprising the Dormitory
quieted to a hushed silence as Dr.
John Curtiss of the Mathematics Department was crowned king of Dormitory Ping-Pong.
The announcement of the conclusion of the tournament and its subsequent victor was
made by Ed Lotz, who conducted the
affair.
Dr. Curtiss was presented
-itir the medal emblematic of his
supremacy by Mr. Lotz, and a garland of choice onions by Mrs. Vanneman.

The champion, who ranks high in
the world of tennis, had to defeat the
very cream of the ping-pong crop in
his sensational fight to the fore of
the field. Putting Vinny Giacinto, the
runner-up in last year's tournament,
to an unexpected defeat, the determined Euclidian then employed all
his knowledge of curves, sines, and
logs, to slip by Lupo Goldstein, taming the Amboy Table Tennis Terror.
Opposing the mathematician in the
final round was Iry Milberg, a freshman, who had made a gallant stand
to this point. Displaying an array of
superb shots, deft drives, and beautiful backhands, Dr. Curtiss soon defefeated the yearling.
When asked for a statement concerning his victories, Dr. Curtiss
could only remark, modestly, "I was
superlatively lucky. My opponents
will tell you the same thing."

Randolph-Macon. The Jays go into
action on January 10 to inaugurate
what will be the most extensive season they have ever enjoyed.
The squad is aided greatly by the

much progress towards the goal of
perfect condition. Although weakened somewhat by the loss of several men, particularly both varsity divers, there is an abundance of new
material to compensate for this.
The contest between Hopkins and
Randolph-Macon will mark the first
time the two teams have met, and
the Jays are anxious to successfully
begin the new relationship. While
the Black and Blue seems to have an
edge, based on last year's performances, the encounter will undoubtedly
be close. Thus it will be necessary
for the Jay, squad to be at their full
strength in order to come out in
front, and Coach Hambleton urges
everyone with any ability whatsoever to report for practice, particularly
divers and free stylers.

only a short period of training, antic'apate a better season than the 1934
one, in which Hopkins could capture
only two of the seven contests. Although the men performed well in
the last few meets, the squad was
very slow in getting into shape. It is
expected that this condition will be
remedied in the coming campaign by
the daily practice in a larger natatorium.

Ed Lotz Conducts
Boxing Practices
After Christmas Holidays
Tournament Is Planned;
Many Attend Practices
Under the tutelage of Ed Lotz,
erstwhile St. John's star, boxing
practices have been held several
times weekly it the Gym. Some ten
to twenty ring enthusiasts have been
present at these sessions.
Preparations for an extensive intramural boxing tourney are being
made. A definite date has not been
ascertained, but Coach Lotz reported that the tournament will take place
a week or two after the Christmas
holidays.
Practices are conducted in a manner closely similar to those of professional fighters. A regular routine
has been outlined. The men do some
shadow boxing, punch both the light
and heavy bags, and often have short
three-round bouts.
After the holidays, there will be
drills on Monday, Thursday and Friday of each week.
Among the gloved athletes who
have been showing ability in the past
Weeks are Fenwick, Glasser, Dukehart, Stevens, Wiseman, Barker, Bravo, Hoffman, and Steingrob.

U.OfM.Booters
Trim Jay Team
In Close Match
Extra Period Tally Decides
Game; Henderson Boots
Winning Goal For Terps
The Blue Jay booters lost their last
game of the season to the University of Maryland soccer team by a
score of 2-1 at Homewood Saturday.
Not unlike their other defeats, this
fatal fracas was a close game, and
was finally decided after two extra
periods.
It was not until the third period
of the game that the Terps were able
to break into the scoreless game with
a fast goal. On a kick in by Beacham, left inside for University of
Maryland, Cissel managed to thwart
the attacks of the Blue Jays and to
force the ball into the Hopkins net
for the first score of the gante.
The Blue Jays immediately retaliated with a goal in the early part
of the fourth quarter. On a scramble
near the Maryland net, the ball was
in an undecided position until Gough,
playing right inside for the Jays,
charged through
with a beautiful
boot which terminated in the Terrapin's net.
The winning goal of the game was
scored in the extra period by Henderson, who played center full for University of Maryland. Henderson
picked a slow roller from a fellow
Player and booted it from close range
into the Hopkins net.
Every Blue Jay boater turned in a
great performance and Coach Dotterweich expressed his satisfaction with
his team. "We'll be right in there
next year with a better and more
experienced team."

Fraternity Sports
•
The last Saturday in January the
Interfrat Basketball and Volleyball
Leagues will be under way. Reuben
Baer intends to have at least two
games before the mid-years. Therefore, there will not be any games
during the last two weeks in January.
All men who are good enough to
play on either the Varsity, Jay Vee,
or Freshman teams, are ineligible for
fraternity competition. Coach Gardner Mallonee will submit a list of
these who are likely to be ineligible.

Life of a joke:
Birth: A freshman thinks it up and
chuckles with glee, waking up two
fraternity men in the back oow.
Age five minutes: Freshman tells
it to senior, who answers, "Yeah, it's
funny. But I've heard it before."
Age one day: Senior turns it in to
campus paper as his own.
Age two days: Editor thinks its
terrible.

The pathetically ridiculous Duke of
Florence was a synthesis of the same
hems and haws of Fabious Maximus.
the Roman patriarch, plus a most
delectable 'ittle lisp. Frank Morgan's
conception in the Hollywood production could scarcely have been far
superior, and it was certainly no more
mirth provoking.
In commenting upon Gerald Branower's performance, it should be noted that the character of Cellini, the
artist-lover-swordsman, necessitates
a certain amount of over-acting.
Cellini was essentially an egotistical,
over-confident Hotspur, and no characterization of him can, or should,
fail to capitalize on it. The key to
his life may be summed up in his own
words: "I am no liar, I ofn a poet.
A liar makes much out of nothing, a
poet makes more out of very little."
Branower was splendid in the role;
and, in his amazing versatility, he
even outdid his startlingly well-done
Hannibal of last year. Perhaps the
balcony scene was a bit overdone, a
bit too rich; but any such slight fault
in dramatic intensity was easily overshadowed by an otherwise consistent
and convincing performance.
A rose to Cyrile Kader Grant for
the most natural and unaffected performance of the evening. In the
Duchess, we find a truly dominant
personality, a real de Medici. Miss
:ant did not act, she was the Duchess—and from her person emanated
all the haughtiness, the aloofness, the
egotism, that characterized the most
dangerous family in European history. That she could handle men-be they Dukes or Cellinis—was obvious. That she could handle herself was even more obvious. In short,
she clearly exhibited all the figure,
bearing, and vocal quality that mark
histronic talent.
It was a far cry from the humble
Punic slave of the Road to Rome to
the treacherous brother of the Duke
of Florence, Ottaviano. Merel Harmel, a sophomore, who is clearly destined to make a name for himself in
Hopkins histronics, has developed
perceptibly since the last Barnstormer production. Making full use of a
remarkably powerful and penetrating
voice, Harmel played his rol,e with a
bearing and excruciating deliberateness that could not escape being admired. Ottaviano was "a real mean
roan," thanks to an exceptionally sensitive interpretation.
Dolly Ashley, we feel, was not very
convincing as Cellini's model, Angela.
The girl whom the artist "picked out
of the gutter" to be his model and
newest love was a cold, rather shallow, emotionless statue whose heart
could not be reached. Miss Ashley
uld have made much of the role
had she maintained throughout her
performance the rigid frigidity which
she did assume on several occasions.
Although there were in Angela neglected opportunities, her part in the
success of the play cannot be slighted.
